title: How to Open Windows Task Manager: Menus, Shortcuts, & More

steps.title: Press the Ctrl+⇧ Shift+Esc keys together.
steps.content: Press the Ctrl + ⇧ Shift + Esc keys together. This keyboard shortcut will open the Task Manager in a new window. You're ready to look through your processes and end tasks! Clearing tasks that you don't need to run is a great way to speed up a slow Windows computer .

steps.title: Press the Ctrl+Alt+Del keys together.
steps.content: Press the Ctrl + Alt + Del keys together. This will open the Windows Security screen. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Choose Task Manager from the list of choices.
steps.content: Choose Task Manager from the list of choices. If you're running an older Windows version, it might be listed as Start Task Manager . This will open the Task Manager in a new window.

steps.title: Right-click an empty space on the taskbar.
steps.content: Right-click an empty space on the taskbar. The taskbar is the bar running along the bottom of the screen that contains your Start menu. Doing so will show a context menu.

steps.title: Choose Task Manager or Start Task Manager.
steps.content: Choose Task Manager or Start Task Manager . It's towards the bottom of the context menu. This will open the Task Manager in a new window. You're done! You're ready to close unresponsive programs and change process priorities .

steps.title: Right-click on the Start button.
steps.content: Right-click on the Start button. It's located at the lower-left corner of your screen. This brings up the Power User Menu. You can also press ⊞ Win + x together to do this.

steps.title: Choose Task Manager from the list of options.
steps.content: Choose Task Manager from the list of options. This will open the Task Manager in a new window. Alternatively, press the T keyboard key.

steps.title: Launch the search feature.
steps.content: Launch the search feature. Follow these steps depending on your Windows version: [2] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source Windows 11 : Press the Start button. Windows 10 : Click the cortana/search bar/icon. If it's hidden, then press the Start button. Windows 8.1 : Press ⊞ Win + Q . Windows 7 and Vista : Click the Start button. Windows XP : This method will not work.

steps.title: Type task manager.
steps.content: Type task manager .

steps.title: Select Task Manager.
steps.content: Select Task Manager . This will open the Task Manager in a new window.

steps.title: Press ⊞ Win+S to open Windows Search.
steps.content: Press ⊞ Win + S to open Windows Search. This method uses the built-in Control Panel app to open the Task Manager.

steps.title: Type "control panel" in the search bar and select Control Panel.
steps.content: Type "control panel" in the search bar and select Control Panel . This will open the Control Panel in a new window. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Type "task manager" in the top right search bar.
steps.content: Type "task manager" in the top right search bar. This will show you a list of results related to the task manager.

steps.title: Click Task Manager.
steps.content: Click Task Manager . It's under the "System" section of the search results. You're done! The Task Manager will open in a new window.

steps.title: Open the Run dialog box.
steps.content: Open the Run dialog box. Press ⊞ Win + R together.

steps.title: Type taskmgr.
steps.content: Type taskmgr . [4] X Research source

steps.title: Press ↵ Enter or click OK.
steps.content: Press ↵ Enter or click OK . This will open the Task Manager in a new window.

steps.title: Open Command Prompt or Windows PowerShell.
steps.content: Open Command Prompt or Windows PowerShell . This can be done by searching for the respective application and selecting it from the results.

steps.title: Wait for the app to fully load.
steps.content: Wait for the app to fully load. You should see copyright text at the top and your user folder path.

steps.title: Type taskmgr.
steps.content: Type taskmgr . [5] X Research source

steps.title: Press the ↵ Enter key.
steps.content: Press the ↵ Enter key. This will open the Task Manager in a new window.

steps.title: Open File Explorer
steps.content: Open File Explorer . It's the yellow folder in the taskbar.

steps.title: Click the address bar.
steps.content: Click the address bar.

steps.title: Type %SystemDrive%\Windows\System32.
steps.content: Type %SystemDrive%\Windows\System32 .

steps.title: Press ↵ Enter or click → to the far right of the address bar.
steps.content: Press ↵ Enter or click → to the far right of the address bar.

steps.title: Find "Taskmgr" and open it.
steps.content: Find "Taskmgr" and open it. It might have ".exe" at the end of the name depending on your file viewing settings. You'll need to scroll down past the folders, which are always placed at the top.

steps.title: Open File Explorer.
steps.content: Open File Explorer.

steps.title: Click the address bar.
steps.content: Click the address bar.

steps.title: Type %SystemDrive%\Windows\System32.
steps.content: Type %SystemDrive%\Windows\System32 .

steps.title: Press ↵ Enter or click → to the far right of the address bar.
steps.content: Press ↵ Enter or click → to the far right of the address bar.

steps.title: Find "Taskmgr" and open it.
steps.content: Find "Taskmgr" and open it. It might have ".exe" at the end of the name depending on your file viewing settings. You'll need to scroll down past the folders, which are always placed at the top.

steps.title: Right-click the Task Manager icon in the Taskbar.
steps.content: Right-click the Task Manager icon in the Taskbar. This will open an options menu. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Select Pin to taskbar.
steps.content: Select Pin to taskbar . This will make it so that the Task Manager always appears in the Taskbar, even when it's closed. You can click the Task Manager icon to reopen it.

steps.title: Open File Explorer.
steps.content: Open File Explorer.

steps.title: Click the address bar.
steps.content: Click the address bar.

steps.title: Type %SystemDrive%\Windows\System32.
steps.content: Type %SystemDrive%\Windows\System32 .

steps.title: Press ↵ Enter or click → to the far right of the address bar.
steps.content: Press ↵ Enter or click → to the far right of the address bar.

steps.title: Right-click "Taskmgr" in the System 32 folder.
steps.content: Right-click "Taskmgr" in the System 32 folder. It might have ".exe" at the end of the name depending on your file viewing settings. An options menu will appear. You'll need to scroll down past the folders, which are always placed at the top.

steps.title: Select Create shortcut.
steps.content: Select Create shortcut . This will create a desktop shortcut for the Task Manager. [7] X Research source In Windows 11, you may need to click Show more options to access the Create shortcut option.

steps.title: Double-click the Task Manager shortcut.
steps.content: Double-click the Task Manager shortcut. This will open the Task Manager in a new window.
